questions.question:
Question 1: A 5-year-old boy presents with weight loss, fever, and a painless swelling in the area of his 
jaw. CBC reveals anaemia and lymphocytosis. Biopsy findings from the swelling are shown in 
the image below. Which of the following is not true about this patient’s condition?

options.a: All forms of this tumour are associated with translocations of the MYC gene
options.b: Endemic forms are latently infected with EBV
options.c: Tumor exhibits a high mitotic index
options.d: Neoplastic cells are usually BCL2 positive

questions.explanation:
The clinical presentation and biopsy findings point to a diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma. 
Neoplastic cells in Burkitt's lymphoma are usually BCL2 negative. The biopsy image shows the classical finding of Burkitt's lymphoma called the starry sky 
appearance. Tumour cells show multiple small nucleoli, minimal cytoplasm and a high mitotic index. They are 
closely apposed to each other forming a dark blue background (sky). The macrophages get stuffed in between along with cellular debris. They are called tingible body 
macrophages. Upon fixation, the cytoplasm of these phagocytes washes away leaving behind white 
spaces filled with debris (the stars). Burkitt lymphoma is the most common NHL in children <15 years. Three distinct clinical forms of Burkitt's lymphoma are: • Endemic- affects children in Africa, affects jaw, maxilla, and is EBV-associated. • Sporadic- in adults in western countries. • Immunodeficiency associated- is associated with HIV infection. 542 
Sold by @itachibot It is the most rapidly proliferating human tumor, Ki-67 stains for 100% of cells (DLBCL- 40% 
staining with Ki-67). Histology shows the characteristic starry sky pattern. Immunophenotypic markers include: • Surface IgM type and immunoglobulin light chains (kappa > lambda) • B cell-associated antigens -CD19, CD20, CD22, CD79a • Germinal centre-associated markers- CD10 & BCL-6 • HLA-DR and CD43 • Expression of CD21 -the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)/C3d receptor, is dependent on the EBV status 
of the tumors • Endemic BL: EBV (+), express CD21 • Non-endemic BL: EBV (--) and lack CD21 expression Treatment must begin within 48h of diagnosis in both children and adults with an intensive 
combination of chemotherapy regimens with high doses of cyclophosphamide and CNS 
prophylaxis.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 7-year-old boy who presented with the following finding was diagnosed with Burkitt's 
lymphoma. Which of the following translocations is most likely to be seen in this condition? 535 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The translocation seen in Burkitt's lymphoma is t(8;14) causing translocation of the MYC gene. 
It is the most common translocation and is seen in 70% of the cases. Other translocations that may be present include t(2;8) and t(8;22).

questions.question:
Question 3: Translocations of which of the following proto-oncogenes is most likely present in patients 
with Burkitt lymphoma?
questions.explanation:
All forms of Burkitt lymphoma are highly associated with translocations of the MYC gene on 
chromosome 8 that lead to increased MYC protein levels. In addition to the MYC translocations in Burkitt lymphoma and a subset of other B and T cell 
tumours, MYC is amplified in some breast, colon, lung, and many other carcinomas. The functionally identical NMYC and LMYC genes are also amplified in neuroblastomas 
and small-cell cancers of the lung, respectively.

questions.question: Question 4: What is the most common site for sporadic Burkitt's lymphoma?
questions.explanation:
Sporadic Burkitt's lymphoma most often presents as a mass involving the ileocecum and 
peritoneum. About 15 to 20% of these are associated with Epstein–Barr virus (EBV). Endemic Burkitt's lymphoma, in contrast, presents as a mass involving the mandible. It shows an 
unusual predilection for the involvement of abdominal viscera, particularly kidneys, ovaries and 
adrenal glands. Involvement of the bone marrow and peripheral blood is uncommon. 543 
Sold by @itachibot Immunodeficiency-associated Burkitt's lymphoma commonly involves the gastrointestinal tract 
(GIT) and central nervous system (CNS).

questions.question: Question 5: Which lymphoma has ki67 index near 100%?
questions.explanation:
Burkitt's lymphoma is a very aggressive tumour, having a very high mitotic index and a ki67 of 
about 100%. ki67 is a proliferation marker used to assess the mitotic index of the tumour. It is high in 
high-grade tumours and low in low-grade tumours. Both mantle-cell lymphoma and DLBCL also have a high ki67, but it is not as high as that seen in 
Burkitt's. Follicular lymphoma is a low-grade tumour, and hence, it has a low ki67 index. The following are the images of Burkitt's lymphoma. • Image a - sheets of medium-sized cells with numerous tingible body macrophages showing the 
classic starry-sky pattern. • Image b - BCL 6 stain positivity in lymphoma cells. • Image c - the Ki-67 proliferation rate of virtually 100%. • Image d - EBER (Ebstein-Barr encoding region) in situ hybridization with numerous positive 
cells. 544 
Sold by @itachibot BcI-6 positivity in Burkitt's lymphoma Ki-67 index of Burkitt's lymphoma EBER in-situ hybridisation in Burkitt's lymphoma 545 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: A 35-year-old presented with fever and ulcerated tonsils. His peripheral smear showed 
lymphocytosis. The Monospot test was negative. Tonsillectomy was done, and the biopsy 
showed the following picture. The larger cells were positive for CD20, EBVLMP1, MUM1, and 
CD79a and negative for CD15. Background cells were positive for CD3. What is the most 
probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) positive diffuse large-cell 
lymphoma (DLBCL). The histopathological findings show large cells with multilobed irregular nuclei. These cells are 
positive for CD20, CD79a, IRF4/MUM1, EBVLMP1. The smaller cells in the background are CD3+ 
which is a T-cell marker. It is seen in the elderly (>50 years) and without immunodeficiency or prior lymphoma. 70% of 
the cases are extranodal and mainly affect skin, lung, tonsil, and stomach with or without LN 
involvement. 30% of the cases have LN disease alone. Option A: This is not infectious mononucleosis as the monospot test is negative. Option B: It is not Hodgkin lymphoma because it is positive for CD20 and CD79a and negative 
for CD15. Option D: It is not EBV positive mucocutaneous ulcer as the patient is immunocompetent and it is 
strongly positive for CD20. Note: EBV positive mucocutaneous ulcer occurs in immunocompromised patients and reverts to 
treating the immunocompromised state. It shows polymorphous infiltrate and atypical large B 
cells with RS cell-like morphology admixed abundant T cells. There is a uniform expression of CD30, MUM1, PA›5, OCT2. There is variable expression of 
CD20,CD45, CD15, CD79a, BCL6.

questions.question:
Question 7: 537 
Sold by @itachibot A lymph node biopsy of a patient suffering from follicular lymphoma shows the presence of 
large cells with prominent multilobulated nuclei and abundant basophilic cytoplasm. Which 
of the following will test positive in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given history and histopathological examination point towards the diagnosis of diffuse large 
B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). It is molecularly heterogeneous and can show the given abnormalities: • BCL6 (transcription factor) overexpression is most common • 10 to 20% cases have t(14;18) leading to overexpression of BCL2 (a proto-oncogene) • 5% are associated with MYC translocations (like Burkitt's lymphoma) • Mutations in gene encoding histone acetyltransferases DLBCL and follicular lymphoma, both are positive for CD19, CD20, CD10, and BCL6 
(germinal-center B-cell origin). While BCL2 is positive in >90% of the cases of follicular 
lymphoma, it can also be positive in DLBCL. To differentiate DLBCL from follicular lymphoma, the ki67 index is used. If ki67 >40% (high) it 
suggests DLBCL. 546 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: You have been asked to use the International prognostic index for lymphomas to predict the 
prognosis of a patient suffering from DLBCL. Which of the following is not the component of 
this index?

options.b: Number of extra lymphatic sites involved

questions.explanation: Hemoglobin levels are not a part of the International prognostic index (IPI) score. IPI is based on the presence or absence of five adverse prognostic factors: • Age >60 years • Raised serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) • Performance status >2 (ECOG) or <70 (Karnfosky) • >1 site of extranodal (extra lymphatic) involvement • Ann Arbor stage III or IV

questions.question:
Question 9: A 55-year-old woman, on treatment for chronic lymphocytic leukemia, notices rapidly 
growing swellings in her neck and axilla. She also complains of fever and weight loss. The 
physician suspects a transformation to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. What is this condition 
called?
questions.explanation:
The transformation of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)/ small lymphocytic leukemia (SLL) to 
diffuse large B-cell lymphoma is called Richter syndrome. It is seen in approximately 5% to 10% 
of the cases. Option B: Chédiak–Higashi syndrome is an autosomal-recessive disorder that arises from a 
mutation of a lysosomal trafficking regulator protein. It leads to a decrease in phagocytosis, 
recurrent pyogenic infections, albinism, and peripheral neuropathy. Sézary syndrome (SS) is a triad of erythroderma, generalized lymphadenopathy, and the presence 
of clonally related neoplastic T cells. These cells have cerebriform nuclei (Sézary cells) and are 
seen in the skin, lymph nodes, and peripheral blood. Kostmann's syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by severe neutropenia. It 
is associated with mutations in G-CSF.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 58-year-old woman came with complaints of swelling in her hard palate. Biopsy from the 
swelling showed the following picture. What is the most probable diagnosis? 538 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given scenario and histopathological image point towards a diagnosis of anaplastic large cell 
lymphoma. The biopsy shows characteristic large anaplastic cells, some containing horseshoe-shaped nuclei 
and voluminous cytoplasm called hallmark cells. 547 
Sold by @itachibot It is a type of T-cell lymphoma that consists of large lymphoid cells. This occurs due to rearrangements in the ALK gene and usually affects children and young adults. 
It frequently involves soft tissue and carries a good prognosis. T-cell lymphomas with similar 
morphology without ALK positivity occur in older adults and have a bad prognosis. CD markers: T cell markers (CD3, CD4, CD8 etc) +, CD30+.

questions.question:
Question 11: Which is an aggressive lymphoid neoplasm that classically occurs in the oral cavity of 
immunosuppressed patients?
questions.explanation:
Plasmablastic lymphoma is an aggressive lymphoid neoplasm that classically occurs in the oral 
cavity in immunosuppressed patients. Plasmablastic lymphoma usually occurs in HIV+ patients (73%), immunosuppressed or elderly 
patients without known immunodeficiency, and EBV+ patients. Lymphomas more specific to HIV+ patients: • Primary effusion lymphoma • Plasmablastic lymphoma • Primary CNS lymphoma

questions.question:
Question 12: A 44-year-old man with nasal obstruction, nasal secretion, and facial erythema was diagnosed 
with facial cellulitis. When his condition did not improve on antibiotics, a CT scan was 
performed. It showed a destructive mass in the right nasal cavity extending into the 
nasopharynx. Which of the following is most likely to present this way?
questions.explanation:
Extranodal NK/T-Cell Lymphoma is most likely to present as a destructive nasopharyngeal mass. 
Less common sites of presentation include the testis and the skin. It accounts for 3% of all non-Hodgkin lymphomas (NHLs) in Asia. Extranodal NK/T-cell 
lymphoma is highly associated with EBV. 548 
Sold by @itachibot The tumor cells typically surround and invade the small vessels leading to extensive ischemic 
necrosis. In touch preparations, large azurophilic granules are seen in the cytoplasm of the tumor 
cells. They express NK-cell markers (CD16, CD56) supporting an NK-cell origin. Most extranodal NK/T-cell lymphomas are highly aggressive neoplasms that respond well to 
radiation therapy but are resistant to chemotherapy.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 63-year-old man presented with severe pallor and giddiness. Clinical examination revealed 
bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. Peripheral blood examination showed lymphocytosis and 
the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear findings showing cloverleaf cells, point towards a 
diagnosis of adult T-cell leukemia/ lymphoma. Adult T-cell leukemia/ lymphoma occurs in adults infected by human T-cell leukemia retrovirus 
type 1 (HTLV-1). Common findings include skin lesions, generalized lymphadenopathy, 
hepatosplenomegaly and hypercalcemia. Peripheral smear blood shows characteristic cloverleaf cells or flower cells which are tumour cells 
with multilobulated nuclei. Lymphocytosis is also observed. It is a rapidly progressive disease that is fatal within months to 1 year. The image given below shows peripheral blood smear findings in adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma. Note: Apart from adult T-cell leukemia, HTLV-1 may also give rise to progressive demyelinating 
disease of the CNS and spinal cord.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 35-year-old man presents with weight loss and abdominal pain. He is a known case of celiac 
disease on a strict gluten-free diet. CT of the abdomen revealed a thickened loop of small 
bowel with stricture and associated lymphadenopathy. A lymphoid neoplasm is suspected. 
What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma. 549 
Sold by @itachibot Individuals with celiac disease have a higher than normal rate of malignancy. The most common 
cancer associated with celiac disease is enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma. It is an 
aggressive lymphoma of intraepithelial T lymphocytes. When the symptoms in a celiac disease patient deteriorate, even being on a strict gluten-free diet, 
cancer must be considered. Note: Small intestinal adenocarcinoma is also more frequent in individuals with celiac disease.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 56-year-old woman came with complaints of pain and swelling in the left side of the 
abdomen. Investigations revealed multiple polyps in the rectum and sigmoid colon. A 
preliminary biopsy report was suggestive of a lymphoid neoplasm. Which of the following is 
the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario points towards the diagnosis of lymphomatoid polyposis. The most common 
among the non-Hodgkin's lymphoma to present like this is mantle cell lymphoma. Lymphomatoid polyposis is characterized by multifocal mucosal involvement of the proliferating 
lymphocytes. It has aggressive behavior and a relatively poor prognosis. It must be treated 
accordingly as a high-grade lymphoma with systemic chemotherapy.

questions.question: Question 16: BRAF V600E mutation is not seen in which of the following condition?
questions.explanation:
BRAF V600E (valine to glutamate substitution at residue 600) mutation is not seen in 
glioblastoma multiforme. BRAF is a serine/threonine kinase positioned immediately downstream of RAS in the MAPK 
signalling cascade. It is seen in the following conditions: • Hairy cell leukaemia • Malignant melanoma • Langerhans cell histiocytosis • Papillary carcinoma thyroid • Pilocytic astrocytoma • Erdheim–Chester disease 550 
Sold by @itachibot Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders
